properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and increasingly humid airmass will continue today. Border line heat warning criteria is expected to be reached again. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can cause the air quality health index to approach the high risk category. Please refer to your public forecast for further details. ### Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-23T05:09:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-22T18:03:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2273316118.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A warm and increasingly humid airmass will continue streaming into the regions from the south. Heat warning criteria is expected to be reached again today. Cloud cover will reduce maximum temperatures below warning criteria Tuesday however it is expected to remain humid. Significantly cooler temperatures will arrive Tuesday night. Please refer to your public forecast for further details. ### Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-23T10:04:33-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall expected tonight through Tuesday. A significant rainfall will begin tonight. General rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm are likely by Wednesday morning in a swath from Sault Ste. Marie to Kesagami Provincial Park. Rain may linger through Wednesday and into Thursday giving additional, although lesser amounts. Localized totals exceeding 75 mm are possible by Thursday. Environment Canada continues to monitor the situation. Rainfall warnings may be issued as necessary. Rainfall warnings are issued when 50 mm in 24 hours is expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-23T11:52:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-22T19:53:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3891371563.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and large hail. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warmer temperatures in the days ahead for inland areas of Nova Scotia Time span: Tuesday to Thursday. Maximum Temperature Tuesday and Wednesday: near 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36). Minimum temperatures Tuesday and Wednesday night: 18 Celsius. Locations: Annapolis Valley, Truro, Pictou and Antigonish areas. Remarks: Another run of very warm days is expected Tuesday to Thursday. Daytime high temperatures will be near 30 degrees with humidex values near 36. A break in the heat is likely on Thursday or Friday. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Information is provided on the Nova Scotia Department of Health and Wellness website at https://novascotia.ca/heat-related-illness/. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-23T10:44:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-22T18:45:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1781381991.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, large hail and torrential rain. Boaters may be caught off guard by strong gusts on smaller bodies of water. ### Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Intense lightning is likely with any thunderstorm that develops. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 39 are expected for the next 2 days. Warm conditions will continue well into the week. Time span: until Wednesday. Maximum temperatures Tuesday 30 to 32 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36 to 39). Minimum Temperatures tonight: near 18 degrees Celsius. Maximum temperatures on Wednesday 27 to 30 degrees Celsius (Humidex 33 to 36). Locations: New Brunswick except the Fundy region. Remarks: warm and humid conditions will continue Tuesday and Wednesday for most of New Brunswick. Southeastern areas may exceed warning criteria again on Thursday before a break in the heat. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 36 will continue. Heat event ending tonight. High temperatures in the upper twenties and humidex values in the mid thirties have been observed this afternoon. Please refer to your public forecast for further details. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 33 are expected for the next 3 days. Warmer temperatures in the days ahead. Time span: Tuesday to Thursday. Maximum Temperature Tuesday and Wednesday: near 28 degrees Celsius (Humidex 36). Minimum temperatures Tuesday and Wednesday night: 18 Celsius. Locations: Prince Edward Island Remarks: Another run of very warm days is expected Tuesday to Thursday. Daytime high temperatures will be near 28 degrees with humidex values of 36. A break in the heat is likely Thursday into Friday. ### Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
